commentBody:
For me, a pleasant themeless Wednesday.

For you?
a dosa is not a wrap
I had to make a lot of corrections, but still did it pretty quickly for a Friday.  Lots of potential alternate answers that were WRONG.
Not as hard as most Fridays, but an enjoyable romp nevertheless.
AYE, I thought this puzzle was OHSO good. There was not much general knowledge, and lots of food for thought: DOSAS, SODABREAD, and RIBEYE, all washed down with some nice REDS.

I'm not sure I'm loving "super-duper" = OHSO.  I'm having trouble articulating why, but here's my shot at doing that (if someone else agrees, maybe they can explain better):

I think of super-duper as meaning extreme but with a positive connotation usually, or at least a lightheartedness to it.  I think the rhyming "duper" gives that lightheartedness.

OHSO can mean extremely, but I feel like more of a negative connotation or negative emotion.  I'm having trouble thinking of a sentence where you could use super-duper and OHSO interchangeably.  Saying something is "super-duper big" carries different connotations to me than saying something is "oh-so big."

For ages, my Saturday best time has been better than my Friday's. It was an aesthetic blemish in the stats section in my games app: a slow, steady increase in the blue average times over the course of the week, and an echo in yellow record times, until the start of the weekend where there'd be slight downtick due to a freakishly easy Saturday from November 2022.

Ever since that freakishly easy, and potentially miscategorized Saturday in November 2022, for every Friday puzzle I've put on my racers hat and tried to right this temporal wrong. Every Friday puzzle since then, I've tried and I've failed, occasionally chipping away at my Friday record, but not overcoming my Saturday.

Until today. Thank you Rafael for making my crossword world make a little more sense!
There is something really satisfying about a classic, solid crossword puzzle like this one. I enjoyed it very much.
Zoe Salda√±a goes ONEONE with Sean Evans taking on the Wings of Death and the Hot Ones HOTSAUCE. She needs a SWEARJAR! lol https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p6wQnvd-S6Y Rafael, boss puzz essie
Becauss of my crossings i really thought 27D was ANISE, because yeah, star anise is a cluster of pods, that makes so much sense, and i didnt know what EDT was nor have i watched good dinosaur yet.

The dual nail polish clues made me wonder about some possible trendy polish color names in the puzzle:

SWEAR JAR
SLAM DUNK
FAJITA
RIBEYE
INSIDE JOB

Hang on - I think almost anything could be a nail polish color!

YETI
WOO HOO
EL DORADO

Help, I can‚Äôt stop.

When I saw Rafael Musa‚Äôs name on the puzzle, I knew I was in for a fun ride. He‚Äôs one of my new favorite constructors. After a tough week, I needed a puzzle clever enough to entertain, but not too hard on my brain. Thank you, Rafael!
ESSIE meeting ARTISTE was my stumper.  The singular in the Cabaret performer finally got me to fix ARTISTs.   Never heard of ESSIE.
Another good puzzle. Got stuck in southwest corner. Had myself going ‚Äúduh‚Äù once I figured it out. Thanks for a nice Friday!
Any Texan can tell you that the dish in 59A is FAJITAS, not FAJITA.
Oppenheimer won Best Picture, not the answer of 6Across in the Mini. Very poorly frased clue.
Solved this one in a quarter of the time it took me to solve yesterday's. Must be my love of Indian food, and my large, multi-brand collection of nail polishes.

I must have been on the same wavelength with Mr. Musa. That was fast solving time for me for Friday, yet very satisfying.

43A was solved incidentally by filling down clues. Wimbledon - lawn, Roland Garros - clay, and Australian Open and US Open are hard courts so I thought it was some acronym for fancy surface until I came to this page. 

Essie - I will have to remember that for future reference.

For some inexplicable reason I woke up at 4 AM (CET) and yet under these weird circumstances I solved the puzzle in Wednesday time (16-ish minutes). This probably means somebody will post about doing it in 4 minutes ü§™.

I enjoyed the solve. Perhaps there were a few too many straight forward clues, but I liked what misdirection there was.

I just don't get why "Go pfft" solves to DIE. To me, "pfft" is the sound of a mildly annoyed sigh, but maybe that's a Polish thing? It was the only area of the puzzle where I struggled today. Spelling LICENcES with a C and not understanding the pfft clue wreaked havoc with spotting DOSAS (I had _OcAS there for a long time). I resolved it in the end but still don't see how the pfft clue works.

SWEAR JAR reminded me of my mother - but not for the reason you might think. She was a published author, university professor, high ranking public servant and recipient of Poland's highest honors for contributing to the discovery and publishing of key details from our history. Always elegantly dressed, she was  partial to a game of tennis and a bottle of good wine. She also cussed like a sailor ü§£. Obviously it rubbed off one me from an early age üòÜ. When I was 12 or 13 she heard somewhere about the concept of a swear jar, and tried to implement it at home to tame my tongue. Soon enough the jar was gone - as it became clear mom would have to feed it more often than me ü§™. The passion with which she said her kurwas was next level. I miss her so üò¢.

I was halfway through the solve when suddenly, wondering who the constructor was of this super-duper puzzle, Rafael Musa came in a flash. And so I checked and... SLAM DUNK, right on the nose. It's a certain style, a certain touch, a sprinkling of current jargon, a WISE and A-LIST kind of thing that has Rafa's unmistakeable fingerprint all over it. And it's a beauty every. single. time. Thank you, Rafa for a [hell yeah!] WOOHOO ride! And now, of course the Brazilian in me must leave you with BOSSA NOVA. Here's Sting singing, with Tom Jobim, the English version of an OLD SONG ("Insensatez" in Portuguese, adapted to "How Insensitive" in English) ‚Äì https://youtu.be/gL6cCNQzOKc?si=SFkxz7OAbsb4D24Z

A classic kind of puzzle, with clever clues and fills that were not a stretch for believability‚Äîa perfect close to a beautiful day. Sunset here, and looking out the kitchen window, the five feet tall geranium has taken on a luminous fuchsia purplish color, and the yard, as it often does at this time of day, looks watchful and almost sinister‚Äîthe plants and trees reveal more personality than they do in full daylight.

An M.R.I. tomorrow morning, and I can almost hear the clanging now.  No big deal. Just another test.

When the geologists formed a band, they rocked!

(They had such a gneiss sound.)
A nail polish brand crossing with pfft crossing with an Indian wrap got me. Once I looked up Gossip N Spill I was still reluctant to let it DIE, but DOSA kind of rang a bell.

Friday PR by a mile - first time cracking 7 minutes. Agreed with some others that FAJITA struck me as unusual in the singular but it‚Äôs not ungrammatical; apparently it refers to a strip of meat, or a little taco made with it, instead of the whole dish that many might picture. I shan‚Äôt complain!

I keep dancing on my own . . .

At the gaybar, a salty patron challenged any comer to fill the swearjar. "GOL!" bystanders shouted as anew word was added. A sweaty Yeti tried distracting her with a sly bossanova, but the dance angels didn't bless him - more REO, less hero. It was a oneone between the Queen of hotsauce and a sexy man-shrub stranger (neatly trimmed WOOHOO!) She said "Letsgo" and added every raunchy ditty, anthem, rocksong, etc, till Yeti returned, begging her askprice for a waltz. "Duh, no."  She turned away, rabid with pride and crowed, "I Juan!" 

"You'd be wise to get on that conga line - when Yeti pines for romance, he means it!" the stranger whispered.

"Ohso that's how it is," she mused, drawn to the tall slice of sodabread who looked like he fell otter a TV ad. "Seems I found my El Dorado."

Sadly, Yeti was having nun of that and he attacked, yet his dazing bonks were no slamdunk so he retreated. 

The Queen of hotsauce cooed, "I care fir you!" to the stranger laid out on the frayed tatami.

"Beloved Nike, stay with me! Let's dance the old songs, and nosh on fajitas at dawn."

"Imokay with that - but make it a ribeye!"

Very smooth sailing but for the SE corner, where pAellA instead of FAJITA made most of the crosses impossible to see.  

Thanks for the fun, Mr. Musa!
Who has SOYSAUCE at a barbecue? in USA?
Dazing? Maybe my vocabulary isn‚Äôt what I think it is. Got both of the nail polishes tho‚Äô. üíÖüèª
I threw away a good 2-3 minutes on my solve time because I opted for the Canadian spelling, DRIVERLICENCES. Nice one, you hoser.

Weird week in that I finished the Friday puzzle faster than the Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.  I think this could have easily swapped with Wednesday, but maybe the clues just jibed with me today where they didn't on Wednesday.

Fun and breezy Friday.
Disappointingly easy even if one is clueless about nail polish.
At first, I showed them my ‚Äòtravel documents‚Äô instead of my ‚ÄòDRIVING LICENCE‚Äô.  Good to have the ‚ÄòSWEAR JAR‚Äô at hand.

[Nail Polish Brand] (3 letters) = OPI
[Nail Polish Brand] (5 letters) = ESSIE

Whuddya say we just go ahead and remember those for the rest of our life now, Striker. 

2 years in‚Ä¶  these should be a gimme at this point. It seems one of the two pops up every couple weeks.  And yetttt. I never remember. Ever. 

(OPI, ESSIE, OPI, ESSIE, OPI, ESSIE)

I was so excited to finally remember OPI, but then they go and toss an ESSIE at me. 

That, plus the unknown DOSAS, made my chances of a lookup-free solve go pffft.

Very breezy for a Friday! I finished faster than my time for this week‚Äôs Tuesday (and Wednesday and Thursday) and only a minute or so outside my Friday PB

Surprised that OPI has only appeared 34 times ‚Äî it feels like every other week..
Got my Friday PB! 11 mins faster than my average, wow. This is the first Friday I didn‚Äôt need any help with at all, not even the wordplays column

I don't usually feel compelled to comment on the difficulty of a puzzle but in this case I do. Maybe it's time to make a case for returning to the greater difficulty level of even a few years ago. For now, playing through the archive is always an option for the disappointed.
Enjoyed this.  However, I could not get the south-east corner.  Ribeyes should not be eaten rare.
Did the easy mode Friday come already filled in?

Like yesterday's puzzle, I was stuck again because  there were three areas of uncertainty.  Did not know DOSAS or ESSIE. Did not know TATAMI, and it took a while for TENS to dawn on me.  But the real problem was that star AnISe is a thing so it took some time to decide it might be wrong. The cluster part of the clue is what made me rethink my answer.  But like yesterday, my persistence paid off with a gold star.

What upsets me about these puzzles as a new puzzler is that almost every clue could be a number of things. I understand that this is what makes crosswords great, but if you have so many options that you can't even hazard a guess for any clue, you can't get any ins to the next ones. So very disheartening if you don't have the encyclopaedic knowledge of precious crosswords
The easiest Friday I've ever done- it was a Monday or Tuesday level of difficulty.

The speedsters seem dissatisfied‚Ä¶ not clear why. After all, if you‚Äôre after a PB why complain that it was too easy to attain. 

I found it a splendid puzzle requiring some lateral thinking and very few facts. Indeed it was somewhat faster than normal for a Friday but still very enjoyable. 

Thanks

Rafael is so easy to vibe with,
he makes crunchy seem smooth.

The answers reveal themselves like fill,
but they‚Äôre *not* fill!

Bossanova, one-one, scions, all aboard‚Ä¶

His puzzles flow like a babbling brook.

Except that tossed in saDSONGS.
Which took me a couple minutes to fix.
Duh!

Don‚Äôt worry, I‚Äôm okay.

Happy Friday all!
I hope something really nice happens
to you, for you, or with you today!

Not all that easy for me, of course. A typical Friday workout but managed to get it all together. Ended up being an enjoyable solve. 

Five debut answers in this one, and was surprised that some of them had never appeared before - e.g. - OLDSONGS and ROCKBAND.

One answer history search was inspired by BOSSANOVA. Looked up the string of letters - BLAMEIT. And.. Nope - never been a part of any answer. Was a bit surprised by that too (some of you will get that).

And, of course a puzzle find today. Quite unusual one. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

Oh, man. Two different lipstick brands and crossing South Asian wraps? It didn't occur to me that one of them was an article of clothing until I filled it in.

Fun stuff, good mix of challenges and SLAMDUNKs, beat my average by about five minutes.

I'MOKAY with it.

A smooth and fun solve but I managed to get myself wrapped up in the South Asian wrap block with my DRIVERS LICENcES entry. I have a mental block on the spelling of some words and that is one of them. Turns out I'm probably just channeling my Scots-Irish ancestors: "License is both a noun and a verb in the United States. If you live in any other English-speaking country, you will spell it licence when you use it as a noun and license when you use it as a verb." "Of course, this source went on to admonish me with: There are plenty of things you can‚Äôt do without a license‚Äîdrive a car, fly a plane, be a doctor, or be a fisherman. And because licenses are so important, you might as well learn how to spell them correctly." Sheesh! https://www.grammarly.com/blog/commonly-confused-words/licence-license/ Nice puzzle by the way and thanks.
So easy, but so fun WOOHOO - with the exceptions of ROCK BAND and OLD SONGS (kind of blah clueing to me, but OHSO). I like DOSAS

Lovely when a puzzle evokes more than simply the satisfaction of a fill-in.  Today:

The sound of a sizzling FAJITA as it‚Äôs set on the table.
The grace and color of a beautiful SARI.
The way OLD SONGS sounded on my transistor radios.  
The cool, smooth, intimate feel of the BOSSA NOVA.
The signature sound of a conductor yelling, ‚ÄúALL ABOARD!‚Äù  
The dense and marvelous forest smell of PINES.

Not to mention, joy at lovely quirks:
The rhyming top line of GAY BAR and SWEAR JAR.
The contradictory neighbors of WISE and DUH.
The vastly different meanings of LETSGO depending on whether or not it has quotation marks.

When the box is filled with little riches such as these, Rafael, it brings treasure into the day.  Thank you so much for making this!
Pleasant puzzle with some nice clues, but more of a Tuesday or Wednesday level. I look forward to the Friday puzzle to wake up my brain, but this puzzle didn‚Äôt quite do it.

I‚Äôm with those who thought this wasn‚Äôt up to Friday standards. Usually the misdirections on this day make it a real challenge. Not so much this time. 

DArING crossing rOE left me flyspecking.
Where's lipstick remover when you need it? Undazing for a Friday.
At first I thought Ms. Swift wanted me just snap but finally just staying made more sense, The "Swift Boat' has left me way behind. This puzzle was a very nice start to the weekend.

Seemed like another "themeless Wednesday" puzzle to me. Breezed through the upper two thirds of the grid, and then had to work just a bit at the bottom.

DAZING is new to me. I'd have changed DAD/DAZING to DAL/LAZING to keep the South Asian meta-theme going.

Why include the question mark with "See what someone is saying?". It's not needed, and this is a Friday puzzle after all.

Maybe I'm just feeling a bit let down after yesterday's stellar offering, but this puzzle and it's cluing struck me as adequate at best.

The Boon Companion was once bitten by an [Overzealous] dog. Sheesh.

Compared to the two-arm stretches of yesterday's cluing, this one seemed Monday-level to me. I knew the Hughes poem, but not the Swift lyric. For once I knew the actor's name, and remembered to spell LICENSE the American way.
Only cause for pause was the nail polish crossing the abbreviated score, neither of which I knew. That would have been a naticky alphabet run, but I got the P on the second guess, based on vague memories of seeing the polish in previous puzzles.
I enjoyed it but this week the Wednesday and Thursday were more difficult.

I've been thinking for a long time the the venerable NYT crossword is gradually getting dumbed down, testing knowledge of pop culture more than words and wordplay.   And two nail polish brands - really?

I thought "Star cluster?" could refer to ANISE...and unfortunately, I had no clue about "The Good Dinosaur" (A dead one? Or...ARNO seemed possible) and even though 43A as EDE made no sense, it was all I could figure out ...and I was ready to be finished with the puzzle.  PFFT, indeed.

For much of the puzzle I didn't even read the clues for the Downs.
Have never heard of DOSAS, ESSIE, ECOhotel.
Back to the Sixties with BOSSA NOVA (no use trying to blame that; it's  Rafael Musa's fault.)

So ...finished with 2 wrong letters.  I don't know if the puzzles are getting "dumbed down," but *I* certainly seem to be.
Hmm, no idea how I got this one. But I did, so I give it a thumbs up. No, I have not stopped whining about things; I'm just taking a hiatus based on today's success.
Good Wednesday puzzle.

So many reasons it wouldn't be the correct answer, but I chuckled thinking that [Establishment that might host a drag brunch] could be nAscAR.

Alien trying to fit in at a concert: "LET'S GO, ROCK BAND!"

Smooth, fresh puzzle. 



Are we there yet?

For 45D [Stunning], I found it unusual that both the clue and the answer (DAZING) were in present participle form (ending in "ing"). Anyone else? I thought there was some sort of unwritten rule against this type of parallel structure, like how a word in the clue can't also appear in the answer, but I could certainly be wrong. At the very least, it seems uncommon. I got hung up in the SE corner for a quite a while because I was sure 45D couldn't possibly end in "ing."
Had to read Ted Hughes poem "An Otter" after seeing 50A.  And the only clue I didn't understand was 'stunning'. Fun crossword.
Two nail polishes seems excessive when you could have clued for actress ESSIE Davis or "Short for Esther?"
Very fun fast solve. I agree about 42A./29D ‚Äì thanks!
Way too easy-even with nail polish brands  and Taylor Swift songs I would never know. Really a Tuesday puzzle maybe Wednesday

ONE-nil to the Arsenal!
ONE-nil to the Arsenal!

...but it wasn't, and Paris Saint-Germain are in the final against Inter Milan tomorrow. It's been a disappointing season for the Gunners.

Rafael's puzzle did not disappoint, though, with plenty of HOT SAUCE for all. I put that stuff on everything!
Easy, breezy & fun.  May the rest of the day be so!
Not particularly difficult but the SW did slow me down a bit
What is it with crossword constructors and nail polish?  Two in one puzzle?

Finished under 8 minutes, very fast for a Friday especially because I also got hung up on the west edge with ANISE for [Star Cluster?].  (If this wasn‚Äôt an intended bit of trickery, it was quite a coincidence!)

I‚Äôm with the fast fun crowd. 

SW did hold me up a bit and I leapt at LEWD for XXX instead of TENS which had me have to backtrack to find my error. 

I didn‚Äôt think TALAMI could be right and thought of TATAMI but then fooled myself into thinking that was seared blue rare beef (no, that‚Äôs TATAKI, doofus!)
The nail polish clues quadrupled my solve time. Brutal clues, a real brick wall for half your solvers.

Star cluster was ANISE for me at first. And of course I thought I was so clever. 

Fun Friday.
Great misdirection! Anise‚Äî I knew Arno couldn‚Äôt be right, but I just didn‚Äôt wanna let go of my star. So, no gold star will have to settle for blue and get back to my to-do list.

The editors do this lovely puzzle a disservice by running it on a Friday, but I enjoyed it. Thank you for reminding me that I have leftover DOSA in my fridge right now, I‚Äôm going to have a great breakfast.

As a relatively new solver, I appreciated this Friday puzzle that I could solve without a lookup. It made me feel as if I am making some headway. I actually knew the nail polish clues from doing previous puzzles. Yippee!  Thanks, Mr. Musa.

I always wonder where I stack up. I'm much slower than those who post their times (8 minutes? I can't even type that fast!)
 Does anyone know why NYT can't or won't post average solve times. Filter out the blue stars, maybe.  I get that you can't filter out the column readers or Google look ups but, hey, doesn't everyone do that every now and then?

This is a confidence booster Friday puzzle.  Feels great going into the weekend knowing you could do this fast and efficiently.  Then comes tomorrow and we will all be complaining about how esoteric the clues and solves are.  LOL.
I really do think I need to go to the drugstore and learn the names of nail polishes.

I'm pretty sure I can narrow down what my last words might be before I pffft. I've had my fair share of near misses. And that doesn't t even include I-285, the Atlanta autobahn. Those words are likely found in 7A, but I think 62A.

I got a chuckle out of 30D, from a line in Private Benjamin ‚ÄúBeware, there are mine fields out there. Most of them are inert. However, some are ert.‚Äù

No nail polish comments, they've been made. After the 1A opener, ‚Ä¶ ah, fugeddaboudit.
It is a good SHRUBbery. I like the laurels particularly.
anybody else use "anise" for the clue "star cluster?" I was so proud of myself for thinking of star anise, and all for naught!

Ooh, that was a swift one. It‚Äôs nice when the puzzle gods throw you a bone. 
Thanks Mr Musa.

Not too tough today, but just right for a very fun solve. I always appreciate doubled clues, so getting two or three of them in a single puzzle (depending on how strict you are) was a fun little treat.
Pure pleasure from beginning to end.

Aye for AYE: Doh!
But I did guess the Swift song --- old guys rule young girls drool.

Thanks Rafael, a smooth solve
Stephen Sondheim on Ethel Merman's contributions to Loretta Young's SWEAR JAR: https://www.instagram.com/reel/CwqrZPTucUZ/ (NSF some Wplaces) And thx for a fun puzzle.
I was sure "star cluster" was "anise".
What a friendly and fun Friday puzzle, especially after some toughies earlier this week!  Thanks, Mr. Musa, it was an enjoyable and challenging 30+ minutes of brain stretching.

Strands #453
‚ÄúAnd here's the kicker ...‚Äù
üí°üîµüîµüü°
üîµüîµüîµ
Needed a little assist to get rolling.



NO SPOILERS UNTIL AFTER VIEW ALL REPLIES PLEASE.

Fun puzzle on the easier side, though not a Tuesday for me.

Glad Anise didn't occur to me. That made room for our old friend Alist to pop in.

Fun puzzle that solved very quickly for a Friday, despite having Travel Documents and Sourdough before DRIVERS LICENSES and SODA BREAD.
Loved the paired nail polish and Indian wrap clues.
Taking nothing away from Rafae,l our constructor, have to agree with those who called this more like a themeless Wednesday.

Very enjoyable and crunchy Friday puzzle with lots of original clues and entries.

Loved the Ted Hughes quote, the cascading earnestness of MEANSIT, ICARE, SEEMS and SLAMDUNK and the four-way natik of OPI, ESSIE, SARI and DOHAS.

I took the bait and got hung up on ‚ÄúWhat the heck IS a Dosa anyway?‚Äù before realizing LIP READS was more apt than LIT READS. Correction made and completion number 2,546 in the books.

Cheers
A puzzle that sinks in its own obscurity and niche cultural signifiers.

Of course my last correction was 20A.

Like D'UH obviously...

Here's a little ditty by a rock band named Electric Six--proteg√©s of the White Stripes, btw: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5WPMP71ngqE (This is not the "official video," but who doesn't love winged, guitar-playing Samoyeds?) Whoa! That's pretty XXX! Better calm down with a little Fran√ßois Couperin: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tCGLATCPAeA (Would have preferred Angela Hewitt performing it on piano, but that's just me.) Fun puzzle, over too quick.

Gay bar! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è How did I get that wrong?? I thought it was wordplay for drag racing and answered NASCAR. 

1D. NOL - must be a British thing
3D. SETI - Yeah I've never heard of it, but the clue did say it's elusive
4D. COSSANOVA - I've never heard of bossa nova either, so why not?

Time to go broaden my cultural horizons and learn more about sports and music.

A classic Chevy kind of crossword. A "n√©oclassicos". More upscale than a Nova...more Malibu or Impala. Rafael might've thought, "mas √© bom o suficiente para mim" He kicked the tires and put it out on the lot. And it sold. A slam dunk for today...I imagine the latter-day-solvers are wanting more chrome. Rightly so I reckon...I miss the hood ornaments and curb feelers too. Nostalgic. Old songs and live rock bands. This grid is well-stocked with the usual off-the-shelf open compound words we used to take for granted. Once. Not now. Chevrolet is celebrating its 100th anniversary in Brazil. General Motors announced it would implement a pilot program called Chevrolet Vintage. Chevrolet Will Restore Your Old Car ‚Äì If You Live In Brazil https://carbuzz.com/chevrolet-restore-old-car-in-brazil/ Thanks Rafael, I hope you have a classic Chevy stashed in a barn in Brazil. ...and WOOHOO...it's Friday! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=725FqPT_xxI
For the one millionth time, no one calls them TV ADS !!
One of my favorite (and my fastest) Fridays. Cheers Rafael!

I had anise there for a long time.
Didn't know the dino
And things are not done on  

/rant
I assume EDT was there as a reminder that Tennis nerds were the original reason for Daylight Savings Time?
I agree that it was a bit more accessible than most Fridays, but it made me feel good. Thanks Rafael.

One of my easiest Fridays, as others have also experienced.  In fact, I think it's a PB (PR) but not according to my statistics.  However, my fastest (16:20) I think is a mistake -- one of those when I lost my internet connection, finished the puzzle without it, came back with a barely filled puzzle, and then sped through to finish.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

WOOHOO, indeed! My first 1000 day streak!

I've broken several long ones on days I was having too much fun to get to the puzzle, but since learning here that I just needed to continue consecutively*, I've been able to have my DOSAS and eat them too. (One thousand days ago, I was in Denver for a four night Phish run over Labor Day. ‚≠ïüï∫üòÅ)

*On the app, anyway. The website shows my current streak is 6 because, you guessed it, I was at my favorite music festival this past weekend and missed Saturday. I remembered to crank it out on Sunday, and was happy to have two puzzles to assist with reentry Monday. (A wormhole to my back porch would have been nice.)

Thank you, comments community, for sharing your insight, knowledge, and stories. This has been pretty fun, too!
Pretty easy for a Friday with a fast solve around 21 minutes.  Really liked the tall stacks of Bossa Nova and El Dorado.  Nice job.

Fast Friday! I recently read the Janet Malcolm ‚Äúbiography‚Äù/criticism of Ted Hughes and Sylvia Plath, so enjoyed the OTTER clue. Highly recommend for a simultaneously engrossing and challenging read.

Always interesting to see how people rate the difficulty of a puzzle. While I wouldn't call this one difficult, I didn't find it as easy as many did. 

Particularly interesting to me, a number of commenters said this was easier than Wednesday this week; I finished Wednesday in pre-teen time, and this one took me twice as long.

@Bob T. I would never say ‚Äúplayed on EDT‚Äù - or ‚Äúon‚Äù any time zone for that matter. But apparently it was used identically in the Times puzzle of December 18, 2020. Which is the ONLY reference Google found of that specific phrase. And yet there was a full AI summary based on that single reference. Makes one wonder about AI, does it not?
A fun, zippy end to my Friday -- 7:54. Thanks, Rafael!
24D was a blast from the past that I didn't get at first...or when I was in high school... anyway this was fun :)
Super fun Friday!

Surely crossword logic dictates that
Evan:Welsh :: Juan:Spanish :: Loo:English

&

Friday:Wednesday :: SLAMDUNK:OREO
EXCELLENT PUZZLE, EXCELLENT CLUES. this should serve as an example! great job! we love :)
I haven‚Äôt read all the comments cuz I am still solving but isn‚Äôt 7A filled with money in lieu of bad words?

I adored this puzzle from the moment I saw Rafael's name under the Play button! That wonderful feeling as one clue after the next just clicks, the squares fill so smoothly you have to take a breath and slow down just to be able to savor it a bit more -- like the best novels or bonbons. Mmmm!!

I really struggled with "Go pfft!"

I'm much more inclined to think that ghosts and genies and leprechauns go pfft when they vanish, but they're still alive.

My mother was the exact opposite.  Absolutely viceless, unless you count chocolate.  No swearing, ever.  When I got a lot older my future wife and I talked her into having a bottle of wine with dinner.  She allowed it, but we had to close drapes so no one could see us.

So I had to pick gutter talk up off the mean streets of Pueblo, CO.

@Francis

That's so interesting! I've always been under the impression that you and I are quite similar in many respects, but apparently not because our mothers were alike ü§£

My mother had many vices, and she revelled in them all ü§™. Speeding, swearing, drinking, smoking, and more - you name it, she did it, probably (I managed to make her quit smoking when I was 12 or so, and I finally talked her out of speeding near the end of her life). She was a great mother though, always there for me. I could - and did - talk about anything with her. She knew how to listen, and she never made me feel like she didn't care about any of my problems. I got so many ideas from our talks, too. Even though she was not a lawyer, her perspective often influenced my scholarly papers. 

Also, only now I realize how she taught me respect for women. She was so much better at so many things than any man! One simply can't have a single misogynistic thought having known a woman like that.

@Andrzej,

That is beautifully said. I‚Äôm certain that she‚Äôs quite proud of you.

@Andrzej

The differences keep piling up.  

This is going to sound like a diss of my mother, but it's really kind of a quintessential America mid 20th century story.

She grew up dirt poor.  Her education was atrocious, and there was really nothing society really offered her, given her lack of any kind of social status.

In spite of not being prepared in any real way by the world, when my father died when I was eleven, she took the reins of our tiny family.  And did so much more bravely than I would have, had something similar happened to me at that point in my life.

So, she got us through it.  It wasn't always pretty, but it for the most part seemed okay.  We certainly never starved.

@Andrzej sure hope I get there! I go between loving them and feeling hopeless! Haha

@Mark The best tactic is to fill in the ones you're surest of first. That sounds obvious, but you kind of have to hold yourself to it. Look at all the clues, across and down, and just fill in the ones you're pretty sure are correct. It cuts down the possibilities for the ones with multiple possible answers drastically, and gains you some traction.

The ideal ones are relatively obscure ones that you happen to know. In this puzzle, TATAMI was a good example for me.

@Mark

Polysemy! That‚Äôs the key to crosswords. 

It means that a word can have several meanings, sometimes completely unrelated (e.g. fare as a payment or as what you‚Äôre served for dinner or a verb meaning how you‚Äôre doing). 

Also, there‚Äôs a vast pool of words that come up again and again (i.e. the two nail polish brands today). 

Practice makes perfect, and you will pick these things up quickly. Two good strategies: practice early week puzzles from the archive, and read the column and all the comments daily. 

You will get the knack much faster than was ever possible when I started solving in the last millennium.

@Mark Some puzzles seem like they will never fill, and it's easy to get a little anxious. But then you see something and that something helps you see something else and before you know you're off to the races.

@Andrzej

If Mark is an Aussie, he doesn‚Äôt know the US sports and standardized exams and other national references any more than you do. And I think your English language skills are equal to most native speakers, and even better than some.

@Mark
I don't know if you know this, but Friday crosswords in particular have an easier clue set that you can sign up for while you're a new puzzler.

It can also help to be a bit counter-intuitive and focus on the Down clues first rather than the Across clues.  In a typical crossword, the longest answers are Across, and the Down answers are often shorter (so fewer options).  The shorter answers aren't the "marquee" answers, so their clues are often more straightforward as well.

But I understand where you're coming from.  This puzzle in particular has a LOT of "crosswordese": REO, GOL, ESSIE, OPI, ECO, etc, which are much more common in crosswords than in real life.  Now, when I see "Nail polish (3 letters)," I know it's OPI, but it took a long time to get there!  And it's harder if you're not in the US and a lot of the pop culture references may not be well-known.  

There are other crosswords that may be easier:  typically, the USA Today and Universal Syndicate ones are easier than the NY Times ones.  I did a bunch of those when I was just starting, which helped me learn some of the constructor techniques for misdirection.

@Mark
Lots of good advice from others, but here's some more:

Grab both a pen and a pencil, and work on a paper copy. Fill in what your absolutely sure of in ink. As for the rest, don't be afraid to make a mistake by filling in what seems most reasonable at first, but in pencil. 

If you have two equally reasonable answers, make a note of both.  Eventually, one of the crossings will probably tell you which one is correct.

Keep in mind that it's always American spelling here (color, honor, realize, license, etc.), and don't be afraid to look some things up. No clue where turpentine comes from? Check the dictionary. Don't know movies? Wikipedia has lists of Oscar winners. Not a fan of (US pro or college) sports? Google is your friend.  (Sometimes you'll have to just look something up just to let you know why the answer you have from crossings is related to the clue).

Today's puzzle was kind, but the Yanks also have a lot (like a LOT) of initialisms that show up pretty often, and for some reason they refer to most of thier Preisdents by the three initials of their names... RFK, RMN, GWB, and so on. 

Oh, speaking of Americanisms, they of course have a different educational system, so be prepared to run across things like PTA, GPA, AP classes, and lots of varieties of _SAT.

As for crossword-ese, well you'll eventually pick that up. But remember this - if it sounds like it might be a field or meadow, the answer is always LEA.

@Bill in Yokohama

I very much distrust my or anyone's ability to evaluate the difficulty of a puzzle.   I don't think anyone really understands why somedays it's a snap, and other days it's a grind.

Large group studies might help, but I suspect small groups would have a tremendous standard deviation for difficulty.

Some suggest going back in the archives to, say, the 90s.  I'm sure those puzzles are more difficult now, at a point in time decades separate from the construction.  But I'm not entirely sure they were more difficult then, in the context of the time.

But I have no proof.  I don't think there is any, or even any unobjectionable evidence.

@Bill in Yokohama

Puzzle difficulty is a topic I am quite interested in due to my time as a test developer. I find test difficulty and puzzle difficulty to be related.

Test difficulty is based on the individuals taking the test and their level of the knowledge/ability being assessed, unless you get into some of the more advanced statistical techniques, but those require a very large sample in order to assess "true" difficulty. 

I see xword puzzles in the same way. Each of us has areas we know, areas we are aware of, areas we have vague memories about, etc. and they differ from person to person.

We don't have a large sample with known measures that we can use to assess the true difficulty of any given puzzle.

If a lot of the NYT solvers know Broadway shows, then puzzles that use those for some of the long entries will appear to be easier. But change the sample to a group that knows little if anything about B'way shows, and the puzzles will appear to be more difficult.

We talk about wheelhouses here, and I think that explains a lot of this.

Maybe an experienced solver here has an idea of what the overall group tends to know and not know, but if the make up of the group changes, then their guesses/estimates will suffer.
This was very easy puzzle, but don't just take my word for it: https://xwstats.com/puzzles/2025-05-30
